title: Z Anti-backlash add-on for Prusa i3

description.text:
My own requirements were:
  • No need to reprint existing parts;
  • No loss of printable space;
  • Use of the PLA property for the elastic force required for the system to work;
  • Easy installation;
    • I think I've made it work... ;) 01-09-2015 Update
    You may experience some wear on both the threaded rod and the nut (especially if you're using z-lift a lot). You can tell when the Z step motor start to skip step and have a hard time lifting the Y carriage.
    I had to replace mine after 6 months of almost daily use and went to stainless threaded rod. The price is ridiculous (2 EUR) and they are far better quality than the original. Nuts should be changed accordingly. Also no need to exaggerate on the torque of the upper nut.
    Added some example of the Z quality obtainable with the help of this add-on.

You need to check the clearance every now and then. If they get too loose, they will have no effect. I had to recently tighten them again... It really make a difference on the quality of the part and eliminate what is sometimes taken for "Z-wobbling".

Sharpie holder I designed to fit on the standard spindle mount that comes with the Shapeoko 2. I needed a holder that was a bit more sturdy so I designed it to utilize all four mount holes and to extend out past the bottom mount. Will have to use shorter bolts instead of the extra long ones that are used for normal mounting of the spindle. Feel free to contact me with any comments, concerns, or questions. Thanks for looking =)
Printed @ .2 height and 35% infill. Flipped it upside down so that the hole for the sharpie wouldn't be a bridge.

I love surf fishing, but I can never get my bait out far enough, so I designed this fishing line servo release system for multirotors. Let your craft take out the bait, then activate the servo to drop the line. It was designed to use a Tower Pro MG90S servo, but other micro servos would probably work. You will need some sort of shaft (I used a 5mm steel shaft piece out of an old printer) and a way to hook it up to the servo. I just soldered a short piece of stiff wire to the shaft and ran it to the servo horn. I printed with ABS set to 0.2mm layer, 50% infill, no supports, and it turned out fairly sturdy. I may do another with 100% infill to compare. Happy Fishing! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wE6zM02mYQY
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kY4JshU99gI

description.text:
Hello, I'm a great fan of the classic robots but I wasn't able to find anywhere a good 3D model of the Gundam Robot to print: all you can find around the web are 3D surface models working very good for renderings and animations, but they are a complete disaster for the 3D printing, even if you apply NETFABB or some other repair software to make them solid. So I decided to make a serious job and completely REBUILD ALL the Gundam in one unique veryfied solid, and after that I made the supports with MeshMixer. The result is (I think) the only one Gundam 3D printing oriented, and after a first printing here you find the file to share it with all of you.
All the best from Italy!

remixed_from.author: inornate
remixed_from.title: Filament Width Sensor with Arduino Pro Micro and TSL1401CL

title: Filament Width Sensor with 3 LEDs, TSL1401CL, and Arduino Pro Micro
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Movie: http://youtu.be/TVAAIxcCAu0 This is an improved version of Filament Width sensor thing #636420, based on shadow casting idea by Flipper's #454584. Now this sensor measures the filament width in three directions: -45, 0, and 45 deg. Three LEDs are sequentially light up and the sensor measures shadows from each direction. It (hopefully) compensate out-of-round filament shape. 45deg measurement limits the maximum measurable filament width around 2.5mm, so, unfortunately, this version is only applicable to 1.75mm filament. For 3mm filament, consider upgrade the line array sensor to wider one, such as TSL1402. Update: Download Filament_Widh_Sensor_3LEDs_forUNO.zip for Arduino UNO board.

• Download the 20150302_Filament_Width_Sensor_3LEDs.zip
  • Prepare PCB and solder the components. (tricky and costly part!)
  • Print case/sensorCover.stl in matt black material. ABS was better than PLA in many cases. If the material is not dark enough, paint the black inside the towers.
  • print three case/led_cap.stl as the cover. mount 5pi LED and cover them with the cap. Connect LEDs like the picture. Aware the polarity.
  • Upload the firmware: Filament_Widh_Sensor_3LEDsFilament_Widh_Sensor_3LEDs.ino. You need to install TimerOne library to Arduino IDE. Refer http://arduino.cc/en/pmwiki.php?n=Guide/Libraries and TimerOne-r11.zip
  • Turn on the visualizer (TSL1401_visualizer) in Processing. (http://processing.org). Through the case, put a 2mm rod as a reference. Type [0, 1, 2] will select the LED and [j, k] will decrease and increase the LED intensity. Decrease the intensity and slowly increase them until the edge detection algorithm works just fine. The green/red lines indicate the detected edge.
    6-1. ([email protected] 26, 2016) If this step crashes and complains about size() function, replace line 31 with [ size (387, 316); ]. Current processing does not allow any variable with size() function.
  • Type [c] to calibrate the sensor. Now you're good to go!
  • If you need more help, type [h] in Serial [email protected] IDE. Look inside the source files.
  • Any suggestion and additional contribution will always be welcomed.
    • BOM)
    1 x Arduino Pro Micro board
    1 x PCB
    1 x TSL1401 Line scan sensor
    1 x 1Kohm resister (SMD 2012)
    1 x 10nF ceramic capacitor (SMD 2012)
    1 x 0.1uF ceramic capacitor (SMD 2012)
    3 x 200ohm resister (SMD 2012)
    3 x 10uF multi-layer ceramic capacitor (SMD 2012)
    1 x 2x3 pin header
    1 x Molex 5046 (right angle, male type mount)
    1 x Molex 5051 (female type socket)
    3 x High-brightness LED (5mm radius)
    8 x 2mm x 8mm sheet metal screw
  • electric wires, pin header sockets, solder, ...

comments.text: First) Please make sure the message "[WARNING] This sensor is not calibrated yet, applying default calibration factor" disappears after the calibration step. This message appears when you press 'h' in Arduino serial console. It should disappear after calibration. When you see this message again after reconnecting the board, your EEPROM must have been damaged. Consider replacing the Arduino board attached to the sensor.

The centerpiece needed 15:20 hours to print. The diameter of this item is around 8 cm.
Printtime for all pieces together is around. 35:12 with my Ultimaker.
The skewers on the side are 15 cm long. For the skewers around the centerpiece I took 8.8 cm.

title: Oh nooo, another customizable thumb wheel / knob / screw / whatever :D

description.text:
I know, there are already tons of them. But I had some specific needs and I simply like to play with customizable openscad designs.  
It would not be worth if it was not versatile so you will be able to design yours according to your needs. I publish it anyway: having more choices never hurts and people may even find that it suits their needs better in some case, who knows ;)  
By the way with one wing only, you can make wrenches!

Use the customizer to set the various parameters such as the number and size of the wings, the nut properties and thickness. http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=70494 To lock the nut in place, one easy solution is to use a threaded rod of the appropriate size, a washer and a butterfly nut as shown on the pictures: align the nut with the slot then slowly screw with force until the nut fully slides in place. I used different ones for my bed leveling and to lock my extruder wheel. It obviously would be useful as a Z-screw adjuster, etc. You can discard the nut completely also. Make sure to check also Harrison's Customizable Thumb Knob (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:45117). His wing shapes are different, and the thing is hollow (may be less robust?).

comments.text: Just a note for users: If you create a hexagonal hole but have a number of wings NOT divisible by 3, your hole might not LOOK like a regular equal hexagon. This is an optical illusion. It can be very convincing. I had to open the STL in modeling software and measure it to be convinced.
comments.author: Charles_Xavier

author: MoonCactus

description.text:
My filament kept catching on the starting connector of my Bowden tube. So I got a pack of dollar-store cheap pencil sharpeners to try.   
Nope. Way too big. So I modeled my own in SketchUp and printed my own to fit the blade they use. Works--after a third revision.

• Slice the STL at .2mm layer height to your printer's needs.
  • Print it.
  • Get a pack of cheap pencil sharpeners from a dollar store or their ilk.
  • Using a small phillips scewdriver, remove the screw holding the blade and CAREFULLY take out the blade.
  • Put the blade in your printed sharpener with the business end over the angled hole.
  • Attach blade with screw form old sharpener.
    • To use:
  • Place sharpener over 1.75 mm filament end.
  • Hold filament firmly and rotate sharpener.
  • Don't push too hard. Let the tool do the work.
  • Removed pointing filament.

I needed a cleaner, less accurate version of another print. I downloaded that print and cleaned it up. I also made the faces even so it would support printing with rafts (required on makerbot mini, which I have). This is not my design what-so-ever. UPDATE Mar 10 2015: DO NOT PRINT. It is a waste of time. For some reason the original designer decided to offset the axis, which causes only 1 out of the 2 axis to work properly. The one that does not work will spin, however it will not spin deg360. I will edit it soon enough.

I found a design and downloaded it. I then removed the intricate stars and designs, as it was messing up the print. (The rafts were not printing underneath. I think it didn't recognize it as a solid.) Now that it is a solid, it should print without error. Finally, I made the faces an even hight, to ensure the rafts would print properly.   
Note: I did not design this at all. Please look at the source below for the original design.

title: Spore to Blender to STL and a Monster!

description.text: A really hideous monster I was making to use for a Chaos Spawn (http://www.games-workshop.com/en-US/Chaos-Spawn). Created with Spore Creature Creator. Full Toolchain details in Instructions.

How to create a creature in Spore and Export eventually to STL.
  • Download and Install Spore (must be v1.05 or later, which as of this writing is a non-issue) (20 US$) http://store.steampowered.com/app/17390/
  • Download and Install Blender, I used version 2.66 (Gratis = free as in beer) http://www.blender.org/download/
  • Open Spore
  • Optional - Play the game!
  • At the galaxy window, hit the create button.
  • Mouse over the paw icon, and click the small paw icon. Then hit the brush/hammer icon to launch the creature creator.
  • Create your creature. Spore requires that you paint your creature to be able to export it.
  • Save (disk icon), but don’t save and exit (check icon).
  • Press Ctrl-Shift-C to bring up the console, while you have the creature in the creature creator.
  • Type “colladaexport”, spore will tell you that a collada file (.dae) has been created, and the file path. Further instructions see: http://www.spore.com/comm/tutorials/export_creatures
  • In Blender, Open up a new file, RIGHTclick on the cube, hit delete, confirm deletion of the cube.
  • File->Import, navigate to the file path that Spore gave you. Further instructions: http://wiki.blender.org/index.php/Doc:2.6/Manual/Data_System/Files/Import/COLLADA
  • You will see nothing. This is because the model is psychotically tiny for reasons that defy explanation. Scroll forward/Zoom in, to almost Blender’s resolution. You should now see your model.
  • You could theoretically pose your model at this point, provided you know how to use the skeleton functions. This needs to be done here because naive scaling does not take skeleton with the model skin.
  • Right click on your model (it should be outlined in orage if you did it right). Hit “s” and “1000” and “enter”. This scales your model by 1000 times. For further instructions see: http://wiki.blender.org/index.php/Doc:2.6/Manual/3D_interaction/Transform_Control/Numeric_Input.
  • File ->Export->Stl (.stl), navigate to your file path of choice.
  • Open it up in your 3D Printer Host of choice, and see if it needs any further scaling. Mine did.

From my reading of the completely draconian EULA (attached and here: http://eacom.s3.amazonaws.com/Spore+End+User+License+Agreement+PC.pdf) this Toolchain is not allowed by EULA, and these monsters are not in fact "yours". The colladaexport tool has the following key EULA provision:
"You may include materials created with the Tools & Materials on your personal noncommercial website for the noncommercial benefit of the fan community for EA's products, provided this is beneficial to the product(s) in EA's judgment, and provided that if you do so, you must also post the following notice on your site on the same web page(s) where those materials are located: "This site is not endorsed by or affiliated with Electronic Arts, or its licensors. Trademarks are the property of their respective owners. Game content and materials copyright Electronic Arts Inc. and its licensors. All Rights Reserved." You will not represent that your site is endorsed or approved by or affiliated with EA or our licensors or that any other content on your site is endorsed or approved by or affiliated with EA or our licensors." Taken from http://sc4devotion.com/forums/index.php?page=6, which is the same EULA as it appears in Spore when you export something. Something close to a legal discussion was archived here: http://www.gamedev.net/topic/542276-spore-creature-export/

title: 36mm Omniwheel
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is an omnidirectional wheel. If you know what this is, you know that they're a real pain to find, and expensive when found. They're expensive because it's a niche item, not because it's terribly complicated or hard to produce -- an excellent candidate for home replication. Unlike commercial omniwheels, this comes with a Futaba-style servo mount already in place -- it's designed to be screwed directly to the servo. If this isn't your style, replace the object named "Servo Collar" in the Blender file with the mount of your choice. v1.1 Update: Based on input from Simon Kirkby, I've enlarged the centers of the roller wheels and changed the axle mounts, which no longer need drilling.

Gather: 8x 12mm lengths of 3mm rod. Slightly smaller rod will also do. Print:
1x omni-36mm-plate.stl
1x omni-36mm-plate-outer.stl (identical, but without the servo collar)
8x omni-36mm-wheel.stl Glue: the plate to the outer plate, with the outer wheel mounts offset 45 degrees from the inner. Mount: each roller wheel on a length of axle. Sand or drill if needed to make it rotate freely. Glue: each axle in place.

title: Strobist style umbrella holder for light stands.

description.text:
I recently found myself in need of an umbrella and speedlite holder for an upcoming photo shoot. I ordered several from Amazon, but they did not ship on time. So I did what any self respecting Maker would do... I turned on my printer, and while it was warming up, I quickly through together a 90Â° Umbrella / Flash mount. This bracket does require gluing, screwing, and tapping. So make sure to read the instructions.   
This bracket will fit on a common photography light stand with a 15mm post mount.

You need to print out the two pieces and glue the shoe mount onto the  bracket. I know this is a quick and dirty design, but I only needed it to last for one shoot.   
The included Hot Shoe' Tripod Adapter is designed by walter and I have added a link to it in the sources section.   
I glue the parts together using Acetone as it forms a "welded" bond and the plastic actually becomes one solid piece.   
Print the umbrella bracket fairly fast with .35 infill and the shoe mount very slow at .25 layer height, and 100% infill.   
I have also included optional (recommended) holes that you can drill and tap for 1/4-20 bolts to keep everything nice and secure.

Stick it on a flower pot to amaze everyone! UPDATE V2.5: Improved Handle. 50% Thinner blades to offer less wind resistance. New e-clips for better construction. Design:
The other day I saw a big metal pinwheel at a local museum that created a cool optical illusion when it rotated, I loved it...
I returned home and began to work on my own printable design. It took many prototypes but I think I nailed it. The special twin blades rotate on opposite directions when the air hits them. The handle has a hole that fits a standard pencil so you can make it longer and stick it on your garden. Check out my other designs here: http://www.thingiverse.com/Dalpek/designs Article from 3dprint.com: http://3dprint.com/48854/optical-illusion-pinwheel/
http://youtu.be/JVeFi31_f-s

Printing instructions: The blades do not require supports.
The handle requires small supports. DO NOT print the blades in different colors or you will loose the optical illusion effect!!
DO NOT print two A or two B blades, otherwise they will not spin correctly. A and B blades are very different, they are designed to rotate in opposite directions. If your slicer is not working with the blade's STLs then try to set your print layer height at 0.2mm or lower. Assembly Instructions: 1-Slide the blades to the pivots on the handle, making sure the flat sides of the blades are facing each other. Note: You might need to sand the pivots a little bit to make them as smooth as possible. 2-Place the e-clips on the pivots and snap them in place at both ends. You can add a drop of oil at the center of the blades to make them rotate smoothly.
Insert a pencil into the handle to make it longer.

comments.text: The handle, clips and side B printed fine. I have had issues with side A printing. I sliced in Simplify3D. When printed, there are gaps in the blades for a few layers. It looks like the blades are too thin for the slicer to recognize the lines in those areas: http://ibb.co/eMRZNv

title: Filawinder servo filament guide leverage multiplier

description.text:
This will increase the leverage of the servo, and keep it from growling, but, at the expense of range movement. As I don't see why it needs to move 180deg. anyways. The pivot is an 8x32x1.25in machine screw and 3 nuts.
the screw gets bolted onto the base, and the bottom spacer drops on that, then the guide with the top spacer, and jam nutted at top.
and the servo gets hot-glued.
You can set it up for whatever spools that you use. I printed the base with a .8mm nozzle, so, the base will probably be a bit sloppy, let me know if it is a problem and I will tighten it up. Use hobby push rod for the linkage, try to set guide in center of spool and adjust linkage so that it is 90deg. to both guide and servo. calculate ratio of guide arm to to servo arm length, and that will be the number that you need to change in FilaWinder sketch/Firmware for guide movement correction. I hope someone finds it useful...

title: Raspberry Pi 2 B Shelf Slide Bracket for Makerfarm i3v 10"

description.text: After trying a couple of different raspberry Pi cases, I started looking at my printer to see where I might be able to attach it directly without it just laying on the table. It dawned on me that I could design a shelf bracket to slide over the wood on the left side & have the P/S support it without having to use any additional hardware. I have printed about 3 hours with it sitting there & it has stayed in place quite well. I have not decided where to put the PiCam yet, but will add it to this design later. I also added 4 wire tie holes on the end if you wish tie your cables off. I used http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:402498 as a guide for the size of the board. I see there is version for the Pi 2 that I did not see before. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:697403

• Print the Bottom & Top Plate or adjust the openscad file to your needs.
    I set the height of the Top plate so you can barely see the red light, so it was not so bright staring at me.
    • There is a version 1 & 2 of the bottom plate. The version 1 is a bit tighter & may require some sanding or filing. With the top plate in place it is pretty stable with the V2 bottom plate.
  • Print whatever Width cover plates you want to using the STL files are adjust Len variable in the Pi_i3vTopCover_V1.scad file.

comments.text: It is a pretty cool little small computer for about $35 that can run your 3d printer. The raspberry pi runs a slimmed down version of the Linux operating system. Octoprint program from http://octoprint.org/ allows you to run and monitor your 3d printer from anywhere in your house or even across the Internet using any device that has a web browser. Also check out https://www.raspberrypi.org/. Someone also rode a plugin recently for the Octoprint that keeps track of the history of your pirnts, but only available in development version so far. https://github.com/imrahil/OctoPrint-PrintHistory

Simple cupholder for mods and/or juice bottles
2 shells, 10% fill

I was really excited after coming across the Keybiner kickstarter (link: https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/fortiusarms/keybiner-the-carabiner-refined) and I did a backing that would get me an aluminum keybiner. I couldn't wait until the couple of months estimated for the delivery to try the idea out-- so I made my own version that you can 3d print or laser cut. This design isn't perfect by any means-- the printed clip doesn't have very much tension, and I didn't spend much time designing a useful hole pattern in the middle the way the real keybiner has (although the largest hex shaped hole is sized for screwdriver hex bits). If I have more free time for this (ha!) the next revision would probably have an integrated clip like the one shown here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:169192 I used 4-40 screws with nylock nuts to hold it together, 1/2" is just barely too short for 2 keys depending on the thickness so I would try using a 5/8" length screw. I've included an stl for the spacer I used, although it hasn't been tested because I just used a nylon spacer that I had. The .stl has the same dimensions as the spacer I used and works well for having two keys.

There is currently no version of the clip that can be laser cut, so you will either need to 3d print it or fashion your own if going the laser-cut route. I originally made the hole sizing to fit wire off a coat hanger, but wanted to make a solution that you could also entirely print. I've also used a piece of raw 3d printer filament (1.75mm) and bent it into shape and used a soldering iron to melt the ends to prevent the filament from coming out. This wasn't as stiff as the printed clip though so it might not be what you want.

title: Hot End Fan Duct Combo - Ord Bot Hadron

description.text: Holds the hot end in place while having a nice duct for a fan. Pretty simple, and it's working great, I like it a lot. The one in the pictures looks rough because it didn't adhere to the bed properly when I printed it -- my fault not the model's. Update: Added a new version: this one has a funnel and aims the air more precisely, although I'm worried that the outlet is too small, I don't feel much air coming out of the tip. Either way, I'm doing an overhang test now to see how it performs. (this test http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:699366) If it doesn't work, I may make another one with a bigger fan and or a bigger outlet.
Print it. I used something like 25% infill; rectilinear.

comments.text: Inkscape 0.92 defines 1" as 96dpi. Go to FILE, select DOCUMENT PROPERTIES, and reset the WIDTH to 3200 and the Height to 800. Then, on the top toolbar, make certain the little padlock-looking icon is set to LOCKED, so that when you shift an object's size, it keeps the same ratio. Select all, and carefully resize down to within the page's parameters.

description.text: Update 2-2-16 Reloaded the files because there were reports of the old files being corrupted. So use the v3 version to be safe. The files otherwise should be safe. This is a mounted spool holder for the Micro M3D printer (not sure if it will fit the Pro). I took two different designs and smooched them together. One from here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:528407 the other was from "Mark" from the M3d forums. Someone else also made spacers for my holder you can check it out here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:753630 They are not necessary and you print fine without them but they can be useful. OK hope you enjoy it!
Notes: You'll need to rotate the arms along the Z-axis: Left arm 105, Right Arm 75

description.text:
This is a token designed to hold a single 13mm dice. I designed these tokens to hold the dice on a certain number to use as indicators of enemies or items during gameplay, or even a turn indicator for other tokens in play. The goal was to keep the dice from rolling accidentally from being bumped or moved during gameplay as well as to give it a small arrow to indicate a face (IE: the arrow indicates which way an enemy is facing if token is being used as an enemy, or the arrow indicates which token the number on the dice is meant to represent. We used these in our recent D&D game to great success - I hope you like them! EDIT: There have been a lot of very inspired very awesome remixes - linking a few of them here since remixes of remixes don't show on the original and I want anyone who checks out this project to see the improved versions made by others! http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:764352
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:783285

Red salt and pepper shaker with unscrew-able top!

Hi!
So this is one simple variant of my phone case design, customized with my company logo. I'll print this in one color NinjaFlex because it's a snapfit with a 2,5 mm edge overlapping all around the screen side (it's important for me to protect the screen) and it would be impossible to snap-in if printed in hard plastic, it would also be impossible to press the buttons.
I made sure the holes can fit all sizes MicroUSB and Earphone plugs and also left a hole for the infrared emitter for the remote control next to the Power button.
More variants to come, in 2 colors, with added shapes like robotic, etc. Please give me ideas and I'll model them and share them. Thanks!

description.text:
This is a handle for a mason jar. If you have ever used a canning jar to drink iced tea (and if you haven't, then brother, you haven't lived) and you wished you had something to hold onto... well, here ya go. The screw-on handle is a stretched out version of:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8793 Going green has never been easier. Poke a hole in the lid of the jar and insert one of them there plastic straw doo-dads, and refill as needed. Be the coolest guy at the river. Drink your coffee in style while you help your buddy winch his truck out of the ditch, and prepare to say "DANG!" as the mud covered bikini-clad hoochy-mammas flock to your side when they see your awesome new mug.

• Print
    i printed:
    -3 shells
    -0.4 layer height
    -25% infill (just for strength)
  • Open the screw side of handle and wrap around the jar under the lip of the screw-top on the jar.
  • Screw on the handle.
  • Enjoy your beverage of choice.
    • The handle is a little big, but i was worried that it would not be strong enough to hold the jar if it were much smaller. I wanted to make a texture on the handle, but had a lot of trouble getting a good one on there... so i settled for rings. This fits Pint size canning jars, but should fit any jar with the standard jar lid size.

Stemmed point knapped by Dr. Loren Davis and scanned at the Pacific Slope Archaeology Lab (PSAL) by Alex Nyers. It was inspired by Western Stemmed points found in the Columbia Plateau which date to the late/terminal Pleistocene. Point was scanned using a David white light scanner. Original material was black obsidian. I added a slightly smoothed (meshlab laplacian 3 step) version to remove some of the noise on the surface of the artifact.
This point has not yet been printed.

description.text:
For the catching of a queen honeybee off the comb. The 4.2mm slots should allow any worker bees accidentally scooped up to come out but keep the queen trapped. Print parts 1 and 2 and use a standard clothespin spring to assemble. The gap created helps prevent squishing any bees.  
I uploaded a version 2 of part 2 of the catcher with a more robust spacing concept, at the cost of a slightly higher pinch chance. I found that even with having multiple height options for the original design spacer, spring variations were too crazy to keep things aligned and properly spaced. I left them for you to tinker with if you like.

Both parts should be oriented properly. Part 1 requires support. I had good success with 2 mm spaced pillar support. Part 2 does not require support.  
I printed mine with 40% infill of 3D honeycomb in PLA and they seem quite strong.

Scales for an archaeological dig. Or a crime scene.  Or, if you're really lucky, a medieval crime scene.  
The big squares probably want a few of them making. You can number them with a whiteboard marker to link up with your field notebook.  
Make these from 2mm white acrylic. If they're for heavy use, acetal (Delrin) is a bit less brittle.

Fairly simple bit of laser cutting, with an ink infill afterwards.   
The grey and black areas are raster engraving to texture the surface so that the ink sticks. Ideally the black should be black and the grey should be an 18% photographic grey (look up "Kodak gray card" for an explanation). This is an exposure scale rather than a size scale, with a standard mid-range colour for printing an accurate rendition of the scene.  NB - I haven't got this to work yet - the search for "grey Indian ink" or functional equivalent continues.  
The line engraving (blue on the drawings) was vector engraving on my machine as this is quicker, but you might find that the lettering is easier as more raster engraving.  
Everything fits onto half an A4 sheet.  
CDR files are the original master, but there's a PDF version too.  
To colour the lettering and the shading, use artist's Indian ink. Wipe this on with a cottton bud, over all of the shading (don't miss any). As it dries, wipe it off gently with a cotton wool pad (makeup removing pad). If it dries too much, use damp newspaper and rub harder!   For any ink infill work, it's important that the sheet used is unscratched on the front, so look after it in storage.

title: Compressed air water draindown adapter for caravans/motorhomes etc. (Truma inlet fitting)

description.text: This device can be used to drain down the water system in a touring caravan (or other vehicle) fitted with a Truma water inlet.  Along with a modified tyre valve and a couple of O rings it works in the same way as a commercial Floe device. Whereas the Floe is around 50GBP this costs less than 5GBP to create. (I can vouch for the original Floe as I had one with my previous caravan however it had a Whale fitting so was sold to someone else.)

To use this you will need two rubber O rings of 25mm inner diameter and 2mm thickness. You will also need a standard car tyre valve  
I printed mine in PLA with 0.3mm layers using Slicr/GPX on a Wanhao 4X.  
Remove the bulbous rubber at the end of the tyre valve leaving just the stem and push it into the barrel (see 4th picture). Slip the two o-rings into their seats (5th picture).  
Insert the device into the water inlet ensuring that it's pushed home.  I found that I didn't need the extra clip but have included it in case the device is slightly too loose.  The clip goes over the tyre valve and mates with the original lip under the inlet where the Truma pistol grip goes.  The clip can slide up and down as required to make a tight fit.  
Close all the onboard water taps, attach a standard car tyre compressor to the valve and bring the pressure up to no more than 15 psi. Shut off the compressor, enter the vehicle and open the first hot tap. The air pressure will force any water in the pipes out through the tap. Close the hot tap. Repressurise and repeat for the remaining hot taps, the cold taps and finally the draindown tap.  
NOTE: I take no responsibility for damaging your water system by applying too much pressure. I used 15 psi as that's what the Floe kit that I owned for my previous caravan recommended.

description.text:
I really liked the design of this cable clip by magicxman but was unable to get it to print. Slic3r had errors with it, I put it through netfab to fix them but the sides would only print about 50%.
So I imported the file to sketchup and pretty much redid it making the sides thicker. I'm not sure what software it was created in but it wasn't a solid shape, but now it is. Other people have printed magicman's version so it must be ok for some setups, just not for mine.
Now Slic3r can handle it and it prints fine on my Prusa Mendal. So if you're having issues with the other file, try this one.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/1a4i5MifEtY

Scale Spoon
The spoon is handled as a normal spoon. But for recipes, it is nice to know the weight of the ingredients. Apart from the loaded spoon with a flexible beam, a second beam is not loaded but carries a scale.
When the spoon is filled, the beam will flex and the scale gives an indication of the weight. The scale has to be calibrated with known weight values. The OpenSCAD file is included to make variations easy to carry out.

description.text: This is for the #CountertopChallenge These shakers will allow you to keep your favorite spices at hand when cooking up your favorite meals. I designed them so that no support will be required. The only overhangs are where the holes are at and the empty space that I created to cut down on the material use. The grooves serve a dual purpose. One, they allow you to grip them easier. Two, they give them a visual appeal rather than just plain cylinders. Suggestions for improvement are welcomed!

Print in different colors e.g. black for pepper white for salt. They have different size holes small is for salt or pepper medium for Parmesan or the like and large for oregano or the like. The screw will fit all three. Shouldn't need an infill more than 20%

description.text:
Are you looking for an easy way to store and manage multiple Mac mini's? Here you go! I developed this simple but elegant vertical Mac mini multi-Dock for our Server-Room where three Mac minis just lay around. With the help of the Dock the Mac mini's now rest nicely organized on the shelf. The Dock is available for One, Two, Three, Four or Five Mac mini's.
Optional cable management rings are included. They allow for easy cable storage, even thick power and network cables fit easily into the rings without obscuring any of the In- or Outputs. The design is made to print without any support. I recommend PLA for this size since ABS will warp and deform. The cable rings can be made from different materials to be more flexible. Approximate Print-Times on Leapfrog or similar machine:
10.5h Single
16.5h Dual
22.0h Triple
28.5h Quad
34.5h Penta The following Mac mini Models will fit:
Mac mini (Mid 2010) = SuperDrive not usable
Mac mini Server (Mid 2010)
Mac mini (Mid 2011)
Mac mini Server (Mid 2011)
Mac mini (Late 2012)
Mac mini Server (Late 2012)
Mac mini (Late 2014) Disclaimer
The Apple Mac mini computer, the Apple Logo, and Product Names as well as Specifications belong to Apple Inc. 1 Infinite Loop, Cupertino, CA 95014, USA.

author: Thedarwin

description.text:
A simple yet effective illusion where the face seems to orientate to the viewer. View the video to get a good look:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3_YqGBlCFZM
Or check out the illusion virtually on Sketchfab: https://sketchfab.com/models/3ada924493804c8f9817bafe44685533 Most people with always see a positive face in a negative face but
the effect works best with a light source shining on it from the bottom which tricks it as if the light is shining from the top on a positive face. Additionally the standing version also works with a light shining through it from the back. (Like a lithophane effect.) Remixed from my Melt Face: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:651829
I squashed, cropped, smoothed and of course inverted it to get a really good illusion effect.

Should print all fine without support.
  • IllusionFace-Standing-ca1.1mm.stl
    Thin double sided version that stands.
  • IllusionFace-Standing-ca2mm.stl
    Thicker double sided version that stands.
  • IllusionFace-Bowl.STL
    A bowl version that can also be hanged on a wall or on a string. Does not work with the light shining through like a lithophane effect.
    • Note: I printed the thin version fine in natural ABS and 0.2 mm layer height. (except the burn mark at the top) The effect works best with a only slightly reflective material. Use 100% infill for the standing version to make sure there will be no infill pattern shining through, not sure if it will print any infill with any of the standing versions. Don't use a transparent material when you want to have the effect with light shining on it from the bottom. It will not really work with it.

comments.text: This is great thank you so much for sharing,....if you dont mind me asking how did you make this file, can any face be used?
comments.author: GyroHeat

comments.text: Theoretically any face can be used but it works best with a face that has not much overlaps, so not much of steep surface. Otherwise it becomes visible through shadow casting and viewing it angled through overlaps. I cropped my face, flatten it a bit and made the nose smoother so it works better and of course inverted it while the standing version is the face with thickness. So you have a positive and a negative side.
comments.author: GyroHeat

This is technical drawing example from the text book "Basic Technical Drawing". From drawing 8-31, this model is a 3D STL file from the 3D sketch from the example.
This model was made in Autodesk Inventor.

As we created lots of wands recently - you can look at those here - we decided to create a nice display to hold and show them. This model is the result of this decision. You can check out how we did it here.

You need to print the top and bottom part + 8 pieces of the pillar (which is a half pillar actually). Then you can glue the four pairs of the pillars together to get the four pillars. Now you need four short piece of 3mm filament: this will be used as a helping material to glue the pillars to the top and bottom parts. It could happen you need to drill the holes a little bit to get a perfect fit for the filament pieces.

author: SpannerHands

description.text:
https://github.com/minad/3delta 3Δ is a host software for 3d printers of the delta style. In many aspects it is similar to Pronterface. However it brings additional motion control better suited to non-cartesian delta printers. List of features:
  • GCode console
  • Connection via serial port or telnet
  • Plots for temperature, temperature deviation and heater PWM
  • Relative and absolute motion control especially suited for delta printers
  • Calibration assistance for delta printers
  • GCode lookup taken from http://smoothieware.org/supported-g-codes
  • SD card upload and play
  • Send: direct playing of GCode files

Just download the file 3delta and make it executable. Besides that you need the following packages which are available under the usual Linux distributions apt-get install tcl8.5 tk8.5 tcllib tklib Then start it with $ ./3delta 192.168.1.x $ ./3delta /dev/ttyACM0 to access your printer either via telnet or via a serial port.

This is very new software! I am using it, but I cannot guarantee that it works for you. But I am happy to help if it doesn't :)  
I am currently using Smoothieware as firmware. Some features might not work with other firmwares since the output format sometimes differs. I would appreciate patches which make this work with other firmwares.  
In principle 3delta should work also under Mac and Windows when the current Tcl/Tk packages are installed. However I didn't test it.
